{"step_by_step_thinking": "Instrumental activities of daily living (IADLs) are activities that are not necessary for fundamental functioning, but they let an individual live independently in a community. These include managing finances, handling transportation, shopping, preparing meals, doing housework, and managing medications. Difficulty in performing these activities can be a sign of cognitive decline. Several studies have shown that impairment in IADLs can predict dementia at 1- and 2-year follow-up. However, it's important to note that while IADLs can be a predictor, they are not a definitive diagnostic tool for dementia.", "answer_choice": "A"}
